children.value: The main theorem is that a functor on a variety (in the sense of universal algebra) has a
if and only if the functor preserves sifted colimits.
The theory of sifted colimits is well explained in Adamek-Rosicky-Vitale. We only cover some highlights.

children.html: A\mathcal AA

children.value: is a variety in the sense of univeral algebra, that is, a category of algebras specified (finitary) operations equations. (We will assume all operations to be finitary in the following, even if we drop the qualifier.)

Sifted colimit preserving functors preserve filtered colimits.

children.html: A\mathcal AA

children.value: are algebras finitely presentable in a usual sense.
Strongly finitely presentable algebra = retract of finitely generated free algebra.
Finitely presentable algebra = reflexive coequalizer of strongly finitely presentable ones.

children.html: A\mathcal AA

children.value: are determined by their action on finitely generated free algebras.

We represent a sifted colimit on Set as the quotient of polynomial functor.

children.value: A functor on a variety has a presentation by operations and equations iff the functor preserves sifted colimits.
To prove “if”, one shows that every sifted colimit preserving functor
